wish.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: if you wish to do something or you wish to have it done for you, you want to do it or want to have it done
wish.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: You may leave now, if you wish.
The cook will prepare whatever you wish.
‘I’d like it to be ready by six.’ ‘Just as you wish, sir.’
I wish to make a complaint.
If you wish to discuss this matter further please do not hesitate to contact me.
wish.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: In everyday English, people usually say want rather than wish:
I want to see the manager.
You can go, if you want.
wish.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to want something to be true although you know it is either impossible or unlikely
wish.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: I wish I didn’t have to go to work today.
I wish that I could afford a new car.
He wished Emily were with him.
Sometimes I wish I had never been born.
wish.translation[0].definitions[1].note_: You wish that you could do something
I wish I could speak Spanish
I wish I can speak Spanish
You wish that something would happen
I wish it would stop raining
I wish you wouldn’t do that
You wish that you had done something
I wish I had paid more attention in class
She wished she hadn’t said that she was bored
You wish that you could have done something
I wish I could have seen his face!
In everyday spoken English, you say I wish I was
I wish I was back home in Hong Kong
In more formal English, especially in American English, you use I wish I were
I wish I were back home in Hong Kong
I wish I were is often used when talking about things that are impossible
wish.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to say that you hope someone will have good luck, a happy life etc
wish.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: My friends wished me well in my new job.
We wish you a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year!
We wish them every happiness in their new home.
He shook my hand and wished me luck.
wish.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to want something to happen or to want to have something, especially when it seems unlikely or impossible
wish.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: It was no use wishing for the impossible.
She was like the sister I never had but always wished for.
wish.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to silently ask for something you want and hope that it will happen by magic or good luck – used especially in children’s stories
wish.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: One day she found a magic ring that brought her whatever she wished for.
wish.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a desire to do something, to have something, or to have something happen
wish.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: It’s important to listen to the wishes of the patient.
Despite her wish to continue working, she was forced to retire at the age of 62.
wish.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a silent request for something to happen as if by magic
wish.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Close your eyes and make a wish.
wish.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: make a wish
He blew out the candles and made a wish.
get/have your wish
She wanted him to leave, and she got her wish.
grant/fulfil somebody's wish
His parents would now be able to grant his wish.
express a wish
He expressed a wish to go to the United States.
respect somebody’s wishes
We have to respect his wishes.
ignore somebody’s wishes
It is important not to ignore the wishes of the patient.
somebody's wish comes true
His wish came true when he was called up to play for England.
somebody’s greatest/deepest wish
Her greatest wish was to see her parents again.
somebody’s last/final/dying wish
Her last wish was to be buried in her husband’s grave.
a fervent wish
To die for Ireland was the fervent wish of every true patriot.
contrary to somebody's wishes
Contrary to her parents' wishes, she decided not to go to university.
in accordance with somebody's wishes
In accordance with his wishes, he was buried next to his first wife.
